title: Doves Type distinguishing features
content: Among Doves Type distinguishing features are: severely curtailed question mark (no top loop); dropped left quote marks (which are a characteristic of some European languages other than English); markedly right-offset dot to the i. Are there any other notable book fonts (i.e. not speciality fonts) that include one or other of these features. Many thanks, Anthony
author: Anthony Barnett

comments.content: Jenson (including the Adobe version) has the rightward tittle (as well as a pretty funky question mark).

Thanks, that makes sense. But the Doves ? and i are so much more marked. The curtailing of the ? gives it an implied feel, which we recognize because of how accustomed we are to a full ? The i is quite remarkable and very effective when following an f

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415061607im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Doves_3678.jpg)

Montaigne and even Eusebius offset the dot on the i as well - but only to a small extent compared with the Doves type. This is because Jenson's own original roman face offset the dot on the i; and many modern Jensons don't include this feature, as it is (and I think correctly) perceived as limiting the potential usefulness of a typeface.

Thus, even Centaur and Cloister Lightface don't do this. So, except for a Jenson aiming at maximum authenticity, the offset tittle is likely something you will hardly find anywhere. As to the question mark, the specimens I saw in a brief search didn't include it, but I think I've seen such question marks before, so there may be possibilities there.
